awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4:NSF: Assessment of Multiscale Air Quality Model (CMAQ) Representation of Spatiotemporal Atmospheric Nitrate Chemical Production in New England
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrate is a key component of the atmosphere that derives from precursor nitrogen oxide emissions that have important implications for air quality, acid deposition, and climate.  Nitrogen oxide emissions are dominated by anthropogenic activities, typically associated with fossil-fuel combustion, which has dramatically declined across the US over the last several decades due to effective regulations.  Yet, atmospheric deposition of nitrate remains a significant environmental stressor.  Atmospheric chemistry transport models, which are commonly utilized to help guide policy, have difficulties reproducing observed atmospheric nitrate concentrations and deposition, resulting in unclear guidelines to improve existing Clean Air Act Secondary Standards. This disagreement may be related to complicated production mechanisms of atmospheric nitrate, requiring a deeper understanding of nitrate atmospheric chemistry to better predict the atmospheric burden of nitrogen deposition.  In this project, the PI will partner with scientists from the US EPA Research Triangle Park to evaluate and improve upon a commonly utilized atmospheric chemistry and transport model’s representation of atmospheric nitrate formation utilizing a novel oxygen isotope tracer technique (Δ17O).  Using a three-dimensional atmospheric chemistry and transport model, this project will enhance the PI’s research expertise and contribute to the training and learning of a graduate student.  This project will establish new and long-lasting collaborations between the PI and host scientists.  Project outcomes will include establishing the first atmospheric chemistry and transport model at Brown University that will be utilized in future research projects by the PI and other collaborators at Brown, enhancing Rhode Island's research capabilities. 

The oxygen stable isotopic composition (Δ17O) has been proven to provide quantitative observational constraints on the production mechanisms of atmospheric nitrate.  This is because key atmospheric oxidants have distinctive Δ17O signatures (or "fingerprints") incorporated in the product nitrate derived from the oxidation of precursor nitrogen oxide emissions.  This work will evaluate the chemical representation of spatiotemporal atmospheric nitrate production in New England from 2005-2017 using the Community Multiscale Air Quality Model (CMAQ).  Model simulations will be conducted using a high-resolution US domain, and atmospheric nitrate formation pathways will be tagged and used to calculate the oxygen stable isotopic composition that quantitatively expresses nitrate production mechanisms.  The model output will be used to compare with detailed spatiotemporal Δ17O observations of atmospheric nitrate in New England, leveraging detailed Δ17O data from prior NSF support to test and improve upon atmospheric chemistry model representation of nitrate chemistry in New England.  The goals of this project include evaluating the chemical representation of the spatiotemporal formation of atmospheric nitrate and differences between nitric acid and particulate nitrate across the northeastern US during a period of significant reductions in nitrogen oxide emissions.  Ultimately, this project will lead to a better understanding of the role of emission reductions on the atmospheric cycle of nitrogen and its connection to atmospheric composition, air quality, and acid deposition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary:  Air pollution from nitrogen oxides (NOₓ), emitted by vehicles, power plants, and industrial activities, continues to impact air quality, public health, and the environment. To understand and manage these pollutants, scientists and policymakers often rely on atmospheric models that simulate the formation and transport of pollutants. These models are typically evaluated by comparing predicted pollutant concentrations with measurements. However, this approach does not reveal whether models accurately represent the complex chemical pathways responsible for the formation pollution, which raises concerns about whether models are getting the right answers for the right reasons. This challenge is particularly relevant in winter, when NOx and its chemical products often remain elevated despite significant declines in NOₓ emissions across the United States over the past two decades. To address this issue, the project developed and applied a novel modeling framework that incorporates stable oxygen isotope measurements (Δ17O) into the US EPA Community Multiscale Air Quality (CMAQ) model. These isotopic signatures act as chemical tracers, providing new insight into the specific oxidation pathways by which NOx is chemical converted in the atmosphere. Model simulations were conducted from 2005 to 2017 for the northeastern U.S. and compared with a comprehensive dataset of oxygen isotope observations. The model performed well in capturing both seasonal and diurnal patterns in nitrate chemistry, and the results revealed that, although NOₓ emissions have decreased, the efficiency of NOx oxidation has increased, due to enhanced nighttime oxidation processes. These findings help explain persistent wintertime NOx-related pollution and demonstrate the value of isotope-enabled modeling in evaluating atmospheric chemistry.

 

Intellectual Merit:  This project has advanced scientific understanding of atmospheric NOx chemistry by developing a new method for evaluating chemical mechanisms within air quality models using oxygen isotope tracers. The integration of Δ17O into CMAQ enables researchers to quantitatively assess NOx chemistry and validate model performance beyond traditional concentration-based comparisons. This framework offers a powerful tool for diagnosing model uncertainties and improving the representation of NOₓ oxidation chemistry, with applications to studies of ozone, particulate matter, and nitrogen deposition. This work has demonstrated at the US EPA CMAQ model accurately simulates NOx chemistry and can be treated as a reliable tool for evaluating future changes in emissions to critical endpoints such as ozone, particulate matter, and nitrogen deposition.

 

Broader Impacts: The project enhances the accuracy of air quality models used by regulatory agencies to inform national standards and evaluate emissions control strategies. The improved understanding of NOx chemistry and its role in air pollution under changing emissions conditions is critical for managing persistent air quality challenges and for developing strategies to combat air quality concerns. The project supported the training of two graduate students, one at Brown University and one at the University of South Carolina. These students gained valuable experience in atmospheric modeling and environmental data analysis, contributing to work-force development. Additionally, the US EPA CMAQ model was set up at the University of South Carolina. This development has helped expand research capacity in an EPSCoR state and created lasting infrastructure for future research. The project strengthened collaborations between academic and federal scientists, and all model tools and datasets have been shared through open-access platforms to maximize their benefit to the broader scientific and regulatory communities.
